data.name: MultipleLogFilesTitle
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance does not support multiple log files.

data.name: MultipleLogFilesIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: MultipleLogFilesDescription
data.value: SQL Server allows a database to log to multiple files. This database has multiple log files which is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance. This database can’t be migrated as the backup can’t be restored on Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: MultipleLogFilesRecommendation
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance supports only a single log per database. You need to delete all but one of the log files before migrating this database to Azure: ALTER DATABASE [database_name] REMOVE FILE [log_file_name];

data.name: MultipleLogFilesMoreInformation
data.value: Unsupported database options in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: MultipleLogFilesMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#database-options

data.name: MIDatabaseSizeTitle
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance does not support database size greater than 16 TB.

data.name: MIDatabaseSizeIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: MIDatabaseSizeDescription
data.value: The size of the database is greater than maximum instance reserved storage. This database can’t be selected for migration as the size exceeded the allowed limit.

data.name: MIDatabaseSizeRecommendation
data.value: Evaluate if the data can be archived compressed or sharded into multiple databases. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: MIDatabaseSizeMoreInformation
data.value: Hardware generation characteristics of Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: MIDatabaseSizeMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/resource-limits#hardware-generation-characteristics

data.name: FileStreamTitle
data.value: Filestream and Filetable are not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: FileStreamIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: FileStreamDescription
data.value: The Filestream feature, which allows you to store unstructured data such as text documents, images, and videos in NTFS file system, is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance. This database can’t be migrated as the backup containing Filestream filegroups can’t be restored on Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: FileStreamRecommendation
data.value: Upload the unstructured files to Azure Blob storage and store metadata related to these files (name, type, URL location, storage key etc.) in Azure SQL Managed Instance. You may have to re-engineer your application to enable streaming blobs to and from Azure SQL Managed Instance. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: FileStreamMoreInformation
data.value: Streaming Blobs To and From SQL Azure

data.name: FileStreamMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/blog/streaming-blobs-to-and-from-sql-azure/

data.name: XpCmdshellTitle
data.value: xp_cmdshell is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: XpCmdshellIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: XpCmdshellDescription
data.value: Xp_cmdshell which spawns a Windows command shell and passes in a string for execution is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: XpCmdshellRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all objects using xp_cmdshell and evaluate if the reference to xp_cmdshell or the impacted object can be removed. Consider exploring Azure Automation that delivers cloud-based automation and configuration service. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: XpCmdshellMoreInformation
data.value: Stored Procedure differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: XpCmdshellMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#stored-procedures-functions-and-triggers

data.name: LinkedServerWithNonSQLProviderTitle
data.value: Linked server with non-SQL Server Provider is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: LinkedServerWithNonSQLProviderIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: LinkedServerWithNonSQLProviderDescription
data.value: Linked servers enable the SQL Server Database Engine to execute commands against OLE DB data sources outside of the instance of SQL Server. Linked server with non-SQL Server Provider is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: LinkedServerWithNonSQLProviderRecommendation
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance does not support linked server functionality if the remote server provider is non-SQL Server like Oracle, Sybase etc. The following actions are recommended to eliminate the need for linked servers: 1. Identify the dependent database(s) from remote non-SQL servers and consider moving these into the database being migrated. 2. Migrate the dependent database(s) to supported targets like Azure SQL Managed Instance, Azure SQL Database, Azure Synapse SQL, and SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine. 3. Consider creating linked server between Azure SQL Managed Instance and SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine (SQL VM). Then from SQL VM create linked server to Oracle, Sybase etc. This approach does involve two hops but can be used as temporary workaround. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: LinkedServerWithNonSQLProviderMoreInformation
data.value: Linked Server differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: LinkedServerWithNonSQLProviderMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#linked-servers

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonBlobDataSourceBulkTitle
data.value: OpenRowSet used in bulk operation with non-Azure blob storage data source is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonBlobDataSourceBulkIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonBlobDataSourceBulkDescription
data.value: OPENROWSET supports bulk operations through a built-in BULK provider that enables data from a file to be read and returned as a rowset. OPENROWSET with non-Azure blob storage data source is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonBlobDataSourceBulkRecommendation
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance cannot access file shares and Windows folders, so the files must be imported from Azure blob storage. Therefore, only blob type DATASOURCE is supported in OPENROWSET function. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonBlobDataSourceBulkMoreInformation
data.value: Bulk Insert and OPENROWSET differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonBlobDataSourceBulkMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#bulk-insert--openrowset

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonSQLProviderTitle
data.value: OpenRowSet with non-SQL provider is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonSQLProviderIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonSQLProviderDescription
data.value: This method is an alternative to accessing tables in a linked server and is a one-time, ad hoc method of connecting and accessing remote data by using OLE DB. OpenRowSet with non-SQL provider is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonSQLProviderRecommendation
data.value: OPENROWSET function can be used to execute queries only on SQL Server instances (either managed, on-premises, or in Virtual Machines). Only SQLNCLI, SQLNCLI11, and SQLOLEDB values are supported as provider. Therefore, the recommendation action is that identify the dependent database(s) from remote non-SQL Servers and consider moving these into the database being migrated. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonSQLProviderMoreInformation
data.value: Bulk Insert and OPENROWSET differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: OpenRowsetWithNonSQLProviderMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#bulk-insert--openrowset

data.name: AssemblyFromFileTitle
data.value: 'CREATE ASSEMBLY' and 'ALTER ASSEMBLY' with a file parameter are unsupported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: AssemblyFromFileIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: AssemblyFromFileDescription
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance does not support 'CREATE ASSEMBLY' or 'ALTER ASSEMBLY' with a file parameter. A binary parameter is supported. See the Impacted Objects section for the specific object where the file parameter is used.

data.name: AssemblyFromFileRecommendation
data.value: Review objects using 'CREATE ASSEMBLY' or 'ALTER ASSEMBLY with a file parameter. If any such objects that are required, convert the file parameter to a binary parameter. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: AssemblyFromFileMoreInformation
data.value: CLR differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: AssemblyFromFileMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#clr

data.name: BulkInsertTitle
data.value: BULK INSERT with non-Azure blob data source is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: BulkInsertIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: BulkInsertDescription
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance cannot access file shares or Windows folders. See the "Impacted Objects" section for the specific uses of BULK INSERT statements that do not reference an Azure blob. Objects with 'BULK INSERT' where the source is not Azure blob storage will not work after migrating to Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: BulkInsertRecommendation
data.value: You will need to convert BULK INSERT statements that use local files or file shares to use files from Azure blob storage instead, when migrating to Azure SQL Managed Instance. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: BulkInsertMoreInformation
data.value: Bulk Insert and OPENROWSET differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: BulkInsertMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#bulk-insert--openrowset

data.name: CryptographicProviderTitle
data.value: A use of CREATE CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER or ALTER CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER was found, which is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: CryptographicProviderIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: CryptographicProviderDescription
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance does not support CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER statements because it cannot access files. See the Impacted Objects section for the specific uses of CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER statements. Objects with 'CREATE CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER' or 'ALTER CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER' will not work correctly after migrating to Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: CryptographicProviderRecommendation
data.value: Review objects with 'CREATE CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER' or 'ALTER CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROVIDER'. In any such objects that are required, remove the uses of these features. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: CryptographicProviderMoreInformation
data.value: Cryptographic provider differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: CryptographicProviderMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#cryptographic-providers

data.name: MIHomogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLTitle
data.value: BEGIN DISTRIBUTED TRANSACTION is supported across multiple servers for Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: MIHomogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: MIHomogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLDescription
data.value: Distributed transaction started by Transact SQL BEGIN DISTRIBUTED TRANSACTION and managed by Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator (MS DTC) is supported across multiple servers for Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: MIHomogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all objects using BEGIN DISTRUBUTED TRANSACTION. Consider migrating the participant databases to Azure SQL Managed Instance where distributed transactions across multiple instances are supported (Currently in preview). Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: MIHomogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLMoreInformation
data.value: Transactions across multiple servers for Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: MIHomogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/elastic-transactions-overview#transactions-across-multiple-servers-for-azure-sql-managed-instance

data.name: MIHeterogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLTitle
data.value: BEGIN DISTRIBUTED TRANSACTION with non-SQL Server remote server is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: MIHeterogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: MIHeterogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLDescription
data.value: Distributed transaction started by Transact SQL BEGIN DISTRIBUTED TRANSACTION and managed by Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator (MS DTC) is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance if the remote server is not SQL Server.

data.name: MIHeterogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all objects using BEGIN DISTRUBUTED TRANSACTION. Consider migrating the participant databases to Azure SQL Managed Instance where distributed transactions across multiple instances are supported (Currently in preview). Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: MIHeterogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLMoreInformation
data.value: Transactions across multiple servers for Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: MIHeterogeneousMSDTCTransactSQLMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/elastic-transactions-overview#transactions-across-multiple-servers-for-azure-sql-managed-instance

data.name: ClrStrictSecurityTitle
data.value: CLR assemblies marked as SAFE or EXTERNAL_ACCESS are considered UNSAFE

data.name: ClrStrictSecurityIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: ClrStrictSecurityDescription
data.value: CLR Strict Security mode is enforced in Azure SQL Managed Instance. This mode is enabled by default and introduces breaking changes for databases containing user defined CLR assemblies marked either SAFE or EXTERNAL_ACCESS.

data.name: ClrStrictSecurityRecommendation
data.value: CLR uses Code Access Security (CAS) in the .NET Framework, which is no longer supported as a security boundary. Beginning with SQL Server 2017 (14.x) Database Engine, an sp_configure option called clr strict security is introduced to enhance the security of CLR assemblies. clr strict security is enabled by default and treats SAFE and EXTERNAL_ACCESS CLR assemblies as if they were marked UNSAFE. When clr strict security is disabled, a CLR assembly created with PERMISSION_SET = SAFE may be able to access external system resources, call unmanaged code, and acquire sysadmin privileges. After enabling strict security, any assemblies that are not signed will fail to load. Also, if a database has SAFE or EXTERNAL_ACCESS assemblies, RESTORE or ATTACH DATABASE statements can complete, but the assemblies may fail to load. To load the assemblies, you must either alter or drop and recreate each assembly so that it is signed with a certificate or asymmetric key that has a corresponding login with the UNSAFE ASSEMBLY permission on the server.

data.name: ClrStrictSecurityMoreInformation
data.value: CLR strict security

data.name: ClrStrictSecurityMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/database-engine/configure-windows/clr-strict-security?view=sql-server-ver15

data.name: ComputeClauseTitle
data.value: COMPUTE clause is discontinued and has been removed.

data.name: ComputeClauseIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: ComputeClauseDescription
data.value: The COMPUTE clause generates totals that appear as additional summary columns at the end of the result set. However, this clause is no longer supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: ComputeClauseRecommendation
data.value: The T-SQL module needs to be rewritten using the ROLLUP operator instead. The code below demonstrates how COMPUTE can be replaced with ROLLUP: USE AdventureWorks GO; SELECT SalesOrderID, UnitPrice, UnitPriceDiscount FROM Sales.SalesOrderDetail ORDER BY SalesOrderID COMPUTE SUM(UnitPrice), SUM(UnitPriceDiscount) BY SalesOrderID GO; SELECT SalesOrderID, UnitPrice, UnitPriceDiscount,SUM(UnitPrice) as UnitPrice , SUM(UnitPriceDiscount) as UnitPriceDiscount FROM Sales.SalesOrderDetail GROUP BY SalesOrderID, UnitPrice, UnitPriceDiscount WITH ROLLUP;

data.name: ComputeClauseMoreInformation
data.value: Discontinued Database Engine Functionality in SQL Server

data.name: ComputeClauseMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/2014/database-engine/discontinued-database-engine-functionality-in-sql-server-2016?view=sql-server-2014#Denali

data.name: DatabasePrincipalAliasTitle
data.value: SYS.DATABASE_PRINCIPAL_ALIASES is discontinued and has been removed.

data.name: DatabasePrincipalAliasIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: DatabasePrincipalAliasDescription
data.value: SYS.DATABASE_PRINCIPAL_ALIASES is discontinued and has been removed in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: DatabasePrincipalAliasRecommendation
data.value: Use roles instead of aliases.

data.name: DatabasePrincipalAliasMoreInformation
data.value: Discontinued Database Engine Functionality in SQL Server

data.name: DatabasePrincipalAliasMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/2014/database-engine/discontinued-database-engine-functionality-in-sql-server-2016?view=sql-server-2014#Denali

data.name: DisableDefCNSTCHKTitle
data.value: SET option DISABLE_DEF_CNST_CHK is discontinued and has been removed.

data.name: DisableDefCNSTCHKIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: DisableDefCNSTCHKDescription
data.value: SET option DISABLE_DEF_CNST_CHK is discontinued and has been removed in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: DisableDefCNSTCHKMoreInformation
data.value: Discontinued Database Engine Functionality in SQL Server

data.name: DisableDefCNSTCHKMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/2014/database-engine/discontinued-database-engine-functionality-in-sql-server-2016?view=sql-server-2014#Denali

data.name: FastFirstRowHintTitle
data.value: FASTFIRSTROW query hint is discontinued and has been removed.

data.name: FastFirstRowHintIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: FastFirstRowHintDescription
data.value: FASTFIRSTROW query hint is discontinued and has been removed in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: FastFirstRowHintRecommendation
data.value: Instead of FASTFIRSTROW query hint use OPTION (FAST n).

data.name: FastFirstRowHintMoreInformation
data.value: Discontinued Database Engine Functionality in SQL Server

data.name: FastFirstRowHintMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/2014/database-engine/discontinued-database-engine-functionality-in-sql-server-2016?view=sql-server-2014#Denali

data.name: NextColumnTitle
data.value: Tables and Columns named NEXT will lead to an error In Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: NextColumnIssueCategory
data.value: Issue

data.name: NextColumnDescription
data.value: Tables or columns named NEXT were detected. Sequences, introduced in Microsoft SQL Server, use the ANSI standard NEXT VALUE FOR function. If a table or a column is named NEXT and the column is aliased as VALUE, and if the ANSI standard AS is omitted, the resulting statement can cause an error.

data.name: NextColumnRecommendation
data.value: Rewrite statements to include the ANSI standard AS keyword when aliasing a table or column. For example, when a column is named NEXT and that column is aliased as VALUE, the query SELECT NEXT VALUE FROM TABLE will cause an error and should be rewritten as SELECT NEXT AS VALUE FROM TABLE. Similarly, when a table is named NEXT and that table is aliased as VALUE, the query SELECT Col1 FROM NEXT VALUE will cause an error and should be rewritten as SELECT Col1 FROM NEXT AS VALUE.

data.name: NonANSILeftOuterJoinSyntaxTitle
data.value: Non-ANSI style left outer join is discontinued and has been removed.

data.name: NonANSILeftOuterJoinSyntaxIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: NonANSILeftOuterJoinSyntaxDescription
data.value: Non-ANSI style left outer join is discontinued and has been removed in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: NonANSILeftOuterJoinSyntaxRecommendation
data.value: Use ANSI join syntax.

data.name: NonANSILeftOuterJoinSyntaxMoreInformation
data.value: Discontinued Database Engine Functionality in SQL Server

data.name: NonANSILeftOuterJoinSyntaxMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/2014/database-engine/discontinued-database-engine-functionality-in-sql-server-2016?view=sql-server-2014#Denali

data.name: NonANSIRightOuterJoinSyntaxTitle
data.value: Non-ANSI style right outer join is discontinued and has been removed.

data.name: NonANSIRightOuterJoinSyntaxIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: NonANSIRightOuterJoinSyntaxDescription
data.value: Non-ANSI style right outer join is discontinued and has been removed in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: NonANSIRightOuterJoinSyntaxRecommendation
data.value: Use ANSI join syntax.

data.name: NonANSIRightOuterJoinSyntaxMoreInformation
data.value: Discontinued Database Engine Functionality in SQL Server

data.name: NonANSIRightOuterJoinSyntaxMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/2014/database-engine/discontinued-database-engine-functionality-in-sql-server-2016?view=sql-server-2014#Denali

data.name: RAISERRORTitle
data.value: Legacy style RAISERROR calls should be replaced with modern equivalents.

data.name: RAISERRORIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: RAISERRORDescription
data.value: RAISERROR calls like the below example are termed as legacy-style because they do not include the commas and the parenthesis. RAISERROR 50001 'this is a test'. This method of calling RAISERROR is discontinued and removed in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: RAISERRORRecommendation
data.value: Rewrite the statement using the current RAISERROR syntax, or evaluate if the modern approach of BEGIN TRY { } END TRY BEGIN CATCH { THROW; } END CATCH is feasible.

data.name: RAISERRORMoreInformation
data.value: Discontinued Database Engine Functionality in SQL Server

data.name: RAISERRORMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/sql/2014/database-engine/discontinued-database-engine-functionality-in-sql-server-2016?view=sql-server-2014#Denali

data.name: DbCompatLevelLowerThan100Title
data.value: Database compatibility level below 100 is not supported

data.name: DbCompatLevelLowerThan100IssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: DbCompatLevelLowerThan100Description
data.value: Database Compatibility Level is a valuable tool to assist in database modernization, by allowing the SQL Server Database Engine to be upgraded, while keeping connecting applications functional status by maintaining the same pre-upgrade Database Compatibility Level. Azure SQL Managed Instance doesn’t support compatibility levels below 100. When the database with compatibility level below 100 is restored on Azure SQL Managed Instance, the compatibility level is upgraded to 100.

data.name: DbCompatLevelLowerThan100Recommendation
data.value: Evaluate if the application functionality is intact when the database compatibility level is upgraded to 100 on Azure SQL Managed Instance. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: DbCompatLevelLowerThan100MoreInformation
data.value: Supported compatibility levels in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: DbCompatLevelLowerThan100MoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#compatibility-levels

data.name: MIInstanceSizeTitle
data.value: Maximum instance storage size in Azure SQL Managed Instance cannot be greater than 8 TB.

data.name: MIInstanceSizeIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: MIInstanceSizeDescription
data.value: The size of all databases is greater than maximum instance reserved storage.

data.name: MIInstanceSizeRecommendation
data.value: Consider migrating the databases to different Azure SQL Managed Instances or to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine if all the databases must exist on the same instance.

data.name: MIInstanceSizeMoreInformation
data.value: Hardware generation characteristics of Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: MIInstanceSizeMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/resource-limits#hardware-generation-characteristics

data.name: NumDbExceeds100Title
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance supports a maximum of 100 databases per instance.

data.name: NumDbExceeds100IssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: NumDbExceeds100Description
data.value: Maximum number of databases supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance is 100, unless the instance storage size limit has been reached.

data.name: NumDbExceeds100Recommendation
data.value: Consider migrating the databases to different Azure SQL Managed Instances or to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine if all the databases must exist on the same instance.

data.name: NumDbExceeds100MoreInformation
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance Resource Limits

data.name: NumDbExceeds100MoreInformationlink

data.name: SystemProcedures110Title
data.value: Detected statements that reference removed system stored procedures that are not available in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: SystemProcedures110IssueCategory

data.name: SystemProcedures110Description
data.value: Following unsupported system and extended stored procedures cannot be used in Azure SQL Managed Instance - sp_dboption,sp_addserver,sp_dropalias,sp_activedirectory_obj,sp_activedirectory_scp,sp_activedirectory_start

data.name: SystemProcedures110Recommendation

data.name: AnalysisCommandJobTitle
data.value: AnalysisCommand job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: AnalysisCommandJobIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: AnalysisCommandJobDescription
data.value: It is a job step that runs an Analysis Services command. AnalysisCommand job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: AnalysisCommandJobRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all jobs using Analysis Service Command job step and evaluate if the job step or the impacted object can be removed. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.value: AnalysisQuery job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: AnalysisQueryJobIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: AnalysisQueryJobDescription
data.value: It is a job step that runs an Analysis Services query. AnalysisQuery job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: AnalysisQueryJobRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all jobs using Analysis Service Query job step and evaluate if the job step or the impacted object can be removed. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: AnalysisQueryJobMoreInformation
data.value: SQL Server Agent differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: AnalysisQueryJobMoreInformationlink

data.name: MergeJobTitle
data.value: Merge job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: MergeJobIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: MergeJobDescription
data.value: It is a job step that activates the replication Merge Agent. The Replication Merge Agent is a utility executable that applies the initial snapshot held in the database tables to the Subscribers. It also merges incremental data changes that occurred at the Publisher after the initial snapshot was created and reconciles conflicts either according to the rules you configure or using a custom resolver you create. Merge job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: MergeJobRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all jobs using Merge job step and evaluate if the job step or the impacted object can be removed. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: MergeJobMoreInformation
data.value: SQL Server Agent differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: MergeJobMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#sql-server-agent

data.name: PowerShellJobTitle
data.value: PowerShell job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: PowerShellJobIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: PowerShellJobDescription
data.value: It is a job step that runs a PowerShell script. PowerShell job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: PowerShellJobRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all jobs using PowerShell job step and evaluate if the job step or the impacted object can be removed. Evaluate if Azure Automation can be used. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: PowerShellJobMoreInformation
data.value: SQL Server Agent differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: PowerShellJobMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#sql-server-agent

data.name: QueueReaderJobTitle
data.value: Queue Reader job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: QueueReaderJobIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: QueueReaderJobDescription
data.value: It is a job step that activates the replication Queue Reader Agent. The Replication Queue Reader Agent is an executable that reads messages stored in a Microsoft SQL Server queue or a Microsoft Message Queue and then applies those messages to the Publisher. Queue Reader Agent is used with snapshot and transactional publications that allow queued updating. Queue Reader job step is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: QueueReaderJobRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all jobs using Queue Reader job step and evaluate if the job step or the impacted object can be removed. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: QueueReaderJobMoreInformation
data.value: SQL Server Agent differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: QueueReaderJobMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#sql-server-agent

data.name: TransactSqlJobTitle
data.value: TSQL job step includes unsupported commands in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: TransactSqlJobIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: TransactSqlJobDescription
data.value: It is a job step that runs TSQL scripts at scheduled time. TSQL job step includes unsupported commands which are not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: TransactSqlJobRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all jobs that include unsupported commands in Azure SQL Managed Instance and evaluate if the job step or the impacted object can be removed. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: TransactSqlJobMoreInformation
data.value: SQL Server Agent differences in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: TransactSqlJobMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#sql-server-agent

data.name: WindowsAuthenticationTitle
data.value: Database users mapped with Windows authentication (integrated security) are not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance

data.name: WindowsAuthenticationIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: WindowsAuthenticationDescription
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance supports two types of authentication 1) SQL Authentication, which uses a username and password 2) Azure Active Directory Authentication, which uses identities managed by Azure Active Directory and is supported for managed and integrated domains. Database users mapped with Windows authentication (integrated security) is not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance.

data.name: WindowsAuthenticationRecommendation
data.value: Federate the local Active Directory with Azure Active Directory. The Windows identity can then be replaced with the equivalent Azure Active Directory identities. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: WindowsAuthenticationMoreInformation
data.value: An overview of Azure SQL Database and SQL Managed Instance security capabilities

data.name: WindowsAuthenticationMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/security-overview#authentication

data.name: TraceFlagsTitle
data.value: Trace flags not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance were found

data.name: TraceFlagsIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: TraceFlagsDescription
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance supports only limited number of global trace flags. Session trace flags aren’t supported.

data.name: TraceFlagsRecommendation
data.value: Review impacted objects section to see all trace flags that are not supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance and evaluate if they can be removed. Alternatively, migrate to SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machine.

data.name: TraceFlagsMoreInformation
data.value: Trace Flags

data.name: TraceFlagsMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/database-console-commands/dbcc-traceon-trace-flags-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver15#trace-flags

data.name: SyntaxErrorTitle
data.value: Syntax issue on the source server

data.name: SyntaxErrorIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: SyntaxErrorDescription
data.value: While parsing the objects on the source database, one or more syntax issues were found. Syntax issues on the source database indicate that some objects contain unsupported syntax in the server version and database compatibility level.

data.name: SyntaxErrorRecommendation
data.value: Review the list of objects and issues reported, fix the syntax errors, and re-run assessment before migrating this database.

data.name: MemoryOptimizedTablesTitle
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance General Purpose service tier does not support in-memory OLTP (memory optimized tables).

data.name: MemoryOptimizedTablesIssueCategory
data.value: Warning

data.name: MemoryOptimizedTablesDescription
data.value: SQL Server provides an In-Memory OLTP capability. It allows usage of memory-optimized tables, memory-optimized table types, and natively compiled SQL modules to run workloads that have high-throughput and low-latency requirements for transactional processing. Azure SQL Managed Instance General Purpose service tier does not support in-memory OLTP (memory optimized tables). This feature is only supported in Azure SQL Managed Instance Business Critical service tier.

data.name: MemoryOptimizedTablesRecommendation
data.value: If you have memory-optimized tables or memory-optimized table types in your on-premises SQL Server instance and you want to migrate to Azure SQL Database, you should either choose the Business Critical tier for your target Azure SQL database that supports In-Memory OLTP (OR) if you want to migrate to the General Purpose tier, remove memory-optimized tables, memory-optimized table types, and natively compiled SQL modules that interact with memory-optimized objects before migrating your databases. You can use the following T-SQL query to identify all objects that need to be removed before migration to the General Purpose tier: SELECT * FROM sys.tables WHERE is_memory_optimized=1, SELECT * FROM sys.table_types WHERE is_memory_optimized=1, SELECT * FROM sys.sql_modules WHERE uses_native_compilation=1

data.name: MemoryOptimizedTablesMoreInformation
data.value: Azure SQL Managed Instance unsupported feature for General Purpose tier.

data.name: MemoryOptimizedTablesMoreInformationlink
data.value: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/migration-guides/managed-instance/sql-server-to-managed-instance-overview#in-memory-oltp-memory-optimized-tables
